titleStmt.title: On the Coinage of Halfpence &
farthings in Ireland by Dean Swift.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: When first the Squire and Tinker Wood,
Gravely consulting Ireland's Good,
Together mingl'd in a Mass,
Smith's dust, & Copper, Lead and Brass,
The mixture thus by chymick Art,
United close in every Part,
In fillets roll'd, or cut in Peices,
Appear'd like one continued Species,
And by the forming Engine struck
On all the same Impression Stuck.
So to confound this hated Coin,
All Parties & Religions Join,
Whigs, Tories, Trimers, Hanoverians,
Quakers, Conformists, Presbyterians,
Scotch, Irish, English, French Unite,
With equal Interest, equal Spite,
Together mingl'd in a Lump,
Do all in one oppinion Jump,
And every One begins to Find,
The same Impression on his Mind.
So Goldsmiths say the Coarsest Stuff,
Will serve for sodder well enoughf,
So by the Kettles loud Alarm,
The Bees are gather'd to a Swarm,
So by the Brazen Trumpet's Bluster,
Troops of all tongues, and Nations Muster
And so the Harp of Ireland Brings,
Whole crowds about its Brazen Strings.
There is a Chain lett down from Jove,
But fastn'd to His Throne Above,
So strong that from the lower End,
They say all Human things Depend;
This Chain as ancient Poets Hold,
When Jove was Young, was made of Gold,
Prometheus once this Chain Purloyn'd,
Dissolv'd and into Money Coin'd.
Then whips me on a Chain of Brass,
(Venus was brib'd to let it Pass)
Now while this Brazen Chain Prevail'd,
Jove saw that all Devotion Fail'd,
No Temple to His Godship Rais'd.
No Sacrifice on Altars Blaiz'd,
In short such dire confussion Follow'd,
Earth must have been in Chaos swallow'd.
Jove stood amaz'd, but Looking Round,
With much adoe the Cheat He Found,
'Twas plain He could no longer hold,
The World in any Chain but Gold.
And to the God of Wealth, His Brother,
Sent Mercury to gett Another.Prometheus on a Rock is laid,
Ty'd with the Chain, himself had Made,
On Icy Caucasus to shiver,
While Vultures eat his growing Liver.
Ye Powers of Grubstreet make me Able
Discreetly to apply this Fable?
Say, who is to be understood
By that Old Theif Prometheus? Wood.
By Jove? (it is not hard to Guess Him)
I mean His Majesty, God Bless Him,
This Theif and Blacksmith was so Bold,
He strove to steal the Chain of Gold,
Which links the Subject to the King,
And change it for a Brazen string.But sure if nothing else must Pass,
Between the King, and Us but Brass,
Altho' the Chain may never Crack,
Yet our Devotion will grow slack.
But Jove will soon convert, We Hope,
This Brazen Chain into a Rope,
With wchÌ£ Prometheus shall be Ty'd,
And High in Air for ever Ride,
Where if we find his Liver Grows,
For want of Vultures, we have Crows.344-103F
